    Access to the accounts resource from the OrgSync API.

    A client to the OrgSync API.

    Access to the classifications resource from the OrgSync API.

    Access to the courses resource from the OrgSync API.

    Access to the events resource from the OrgSync API.
    ExportsResource
    Access to data exports from the API, which provide a convienient way to request large amounts of data in a single call.

    Access to the forms resource from the OrgSync API.
    GroupsResource
    Access to the groups resource from the OrgSync API.

    Access to the identification cards resource from the OrgSync API.

    Access to the membership log entries resource from the OrgSync API.

    Access to the organizations resource from the OrgSync API.
    TimesheetsResource
    Access to the timesheets resource from the OrgSync API.

    The entry point for creating clients for the OrgSync API V2.

    A Resource factory really.

    Constants to pass to ApiClient.getResource(Resource) to retrieve access to a given resource.

    ApiClientException

Package com.orgsync.api Description

Orgsync API (V2)

This package provides access to the OrgSync API version 2. The OrgSync class provides access to the clients that can be used with the API. While many part of this library are well documented, others are left intentionally vauge since the API documentation should be consulted:

https://api.orgsync.com/api/docs/v2

Retrieving a Client

To retrieve a client, use the OrgSync.newApiClient(String) method and pass in your OrgSync API key. The returned client provides access to the various resources provided by the API.

The client uses the Async HTTP Client under the hood to handle the communication with the REST API. A default client is created by the client. However, if a user needs to customize the settings for this client, a new HTTP client can be set using the ApiClient.setHttpClient(com.ning.http.client.AsyncHttpClient) method. Most users of this API will not need to use this.

Accessing Resources

The various Resources provide access to the data available in the API. The ApiClient.getResource(Resource) call is used to retrieve these resources. The list of possible resources to access are defined in the Resources class as constants. Each Resource returns a different type based on its parameterized type.

Accessing Data from a Resource

Each resource has methods that match the various endpoints that are made available in the API documentation. However, there are some common patterns that are used by each of the resources.

All calls return a ListenableFuture of a ApiResponse. The future is just a handle to work that will be available at some point in the future. To block and wait for the response, simply call the Future.get() method. A Future is returned so that users that want to make the application fully asynchronous have that options. Otherwise, using the Future.get() method results in a normal blocking style of use.

The ApiResponse encapsulates the fact that any call to the API can fail for many reasons (e.g. passing an invalid ID). For this reason, any call can return either a success or a failure. The ApiResponse.isSuccess() method is used to determine if the call was successful. If it was, the correct result is available using the ApiResponse.getResult() method. If the call failed (meaning ApiResponse.isSuccess() is false), then the ApiResponse.getError() method returns an ApiError which makes the message available using the ApiError.getMessage() call.

A call to the API can fail for other reasons (e.g. networking issues). If for any reason the API client cannot reach the API, a ApiClientException will be thrown and the underlying exception can be retrieved using Throwable.getCause().

Making Updates

Some resources allow various fields to be updated. If all fields are required for an update, then generally they are required as parameters to the update method. If only a few of many fields can be accessed then a request object may be required. For instance, to update an account a user can use the AccountUpdateRequest object. This class provides various setter methods for the data that can be updated (e.g. AccountUpdateRequest.setFirstName(String)). Each of these setters returns the object so that they can be fluently chained:

AccountUpdateRequest request = new AccountUpdateRequest().setFirstName("Joan").setLastName("Smith")
